claims: Primary Types
Name: Write-through cache
Description: Immediately updates both the cache and the main memory when data is modified
Pros: Ensures data consistency
Cons: May slow down write operations
Name: Write-back cache
Description: Only updates the cache initially and defers updating the main memory until necessary
Pros: Improves write performance
Cons: Risks data inconsistency if not managed properly
Implementation Strategy: Often involves a combination of different cache types to balance performance and consistency requirements.
fact_usage: Cache types are fundamental to understanding caching implementation.
The two primary cache types are write-through and write-back caches.
Write-through caches immediately update both the cache and the main memory when data is modified, ensuring consistency but potentially slowing write operations.

Write-back caches, on the other hand, only update the cache initially and defer updating the main memory until necessary, improving write performance but risking data inconsistency if not managed properly.
Caching implementation strategies often involve a combination of different cache types to balance performance and consistency requirements.

Cache Types.score_rationale: All claims are directly supported by the facts provided in the original context.

claims: MFA typically involves a combination of: Something you know, Something you have, Something you are
Common methods include SMS-based OTP, Authenticator apps generating time-based OTPs, Hardware tokens, Biometric factors

Security tokens types: Hardware tokens, Software tokens
Functionality: Generate one-time passwords using cryptographic algorithms
Validity period: Usually 30 to 60 seconds
fact_usage: Multi-factor authentication (MFA) typically involves a combination of something you know (like a password), something you have (like a security token), and something you are (like biometric data).

The most common MFA methods include SMS-based one-time passwords (OTP), authenticator apps generating time-based OTPs, hardware tokens, and biometric factors such as fingerprints or facial recognition.
Biometric factors in MFA can include fingerprints, facial recognition, voice recognition, or even iris scans.
These factors are considered highly secure as they are unique to each individual and difficult to replicate.
However, the implementation of biometric authentication requires specialized hardware and software, which can increase the complexity and cost of the MFA system.
Security tokens come in various forms, including hardware tokens and software tokens.
Hardware tokens are physical devices that generate one-time passwords, while software tokens are typically smartphone apps that serve the same purpose.
Both types of tokens use cryptographic algorithms to generate unique codes that are valid for a short period, usually 30 to 60 seconds.

Authentication Methods.score_rationale: The response accurately reflects the context-provided information on authentication methods, covering types, functionality, and validity periods of tokens without introducing unsupported claims.
